document.discussion_title: 'Isis child suicide bomber' stripped of explosive belt before attack in Iraq | Middle East | News
document.topic_text: Footage has emerged purportedly showing the arrest of an Isis boy suicide bomber , thought to be as young as 12 years old. Video of the arrest shows Iraqi security forces removing a suicide bomb vest from the young boy. The boy, aged between 12 and 13, appeared to burst into tears as he was captured by police in Kirkuk, Iraq, on Sunday. Iraqi security forces detain a boy after removing a suicide vest from him in Kirkuk, Iraq, 21 August, 2016 (Reuters) The explosives vest was later detonated in a controlled explosion. It is currently unclear whether the boy wanted to carry out the attack himself or was forced into it by the jihadi group. Iraqi security forces detain a boy after removing a suicide vest from him in Kirkuk, Iraq, 21 August, 2016 (Reuters) Read more Turkey wedding bomb: Suicide bomber who killed at least 51 was between 12 and 14 years old, says President Erdogan Turkey wedding bomb: Death toll rises to 50 after 'Isis' terror attack as suicide vest found at blast scene Iraq executes 36 men convicted of Isis massacre that killed 1,700 Isis claims responsibility for first terror attack in Russia after men try to kill police with gun and axes near Moscow Hours earlier, a suicide bomber blew himself up in front of a Shia shrine in Kirkuk, injuring three people. The attack followed another suicide bombing in the same neighbourhood that caused no casualties. “There is a dangerous campaign tonight against Kirkuk,” a security official told Kurdish news agency Rudaw . Iraqi security forces remove a suicide vest from a boy in Kirkuk, Iraq, 21 August, 2016. (Reuters) On Saturday, Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan said an Isis child suicide bomber as young as 12 was behind an attack on a Kurdish wedding which killed at least 51 people. At least 22 of the victims were under the age of 14, a government official said. Isis has deployed child suicide bombers to stage attacks in both Iraq and Syria. Among the most deadly attacks was a bombing at a youth football match at a stadium south of Baghdad on 25 March, 2016.
